data.source: Unacast anonymized cell phone mobility data; American Community Survey (ACS, 2014–2018 5-year averages); MIT Election Data and Science Lab; 2010 Census (rurality)
data.wave_or_subset: March 19–28, 2020 relative to matched days of a pre-COVID-19 reference week; 3,037 U.S. counties
data.access_details: Unacast social distancing dataset provided for research use (Acknowledgments); ACS, MIT Election Data and Science Lab, and Census obtained from respective sources; specific access links not stated
data.notes: Outcome is percentage-point change in average distance traveled; negative values indicate greater social distancing. Based on 15–17 million anonymous cell phone users per day. Mobility decreased by 27.3 percentage points in the median county during March 19–28. Rurality from 2010 Census. State fixed effects used.

method.description: The study used county-level mobility data from anonymized cell phone records to quantify changes in distance traveled during March 19–28, 2020 relative to a pre-COVID-19 reference week. It examined associations between social distancing and county socioeconomic status (per capita income) and political orientation (2016 Trump vote share) using cross-sectional ordinary least squares regressions, adjusting for sociodemographic composition, labor market structure, rurality, and state fixed effects.
steps: Obtain county-level mobility metrics (average distance traveled) from Unacast for March 19–28, 2020 and matched pre-COVID-19 reference days.
Compute percentage-point change in average mobility relative to the pre-COVID-19 reference week (negative indicates more social distancing).
Assemble county-level exposures: per capita income (ACS 2014–2018) and 2016 Trump vote share (MIT Election Data and Science Lab).

Assemble covariates: percentage male, Black, Hispanic; age distribution; share with college degree; shares employed in retail, transportation, and health/education/social services (ACS); rurality from 2010 Census.
Conduct bivariate linear analyses of mobility change vs. per capita income and Trump vote share (Figure 1B, 1C).
Estimate multivariable cross-sectional OLS regressions of mobility change on exposures, controlling for covariates, rurality, and including state fixed effects (Table 1).
Interpret coefficients as percentage-point changes in mobility per interquartile range (IQR) change in each predictor; assess statistical significance using 95% confidence intervals and p-values.
method.models: Cross-sectional ordinary least squares regression with state fixed effects; bivariate linear regressions for visualization; multivariable OLS including sociodemographic and labor market covariates and rurality
method.outcome_variable: Percentage-point change in average county mobility (average distance traveled) during March 19–28, 2020 relative to matched days of a pre-COVID-19 reference week (negative indicates greater social distancing)
method.independent_variables: Per capita income; 2016 county-level vote share for President Trump
method.control_variables: Percentage male; percentage Black; percentage Hispanic; age distribution (percentage for each decade of life); percentage with college degree; employment shares in retail, transportation, and health/education/social services; percentage rural; state fixed effects

results.summary: Lower per capita income and higher 2016 Trump vote share were associated with reduced social distancing. In multivariable models, an interquartile increase in per capita income was associated with a 1.36 percentage-point decrease in mobility (i.e., more distancing), whereas an interquartile increase in Trump vote share was associated with a 4.12 percentage-point increase in mobility (i.e., less distancing). Higher shares of racial minorities and lower educational attainment were linked to less distancing; gender and age shares were not significant.

numerical_results.outcome_name: Change in average county mobility (pp) per IQR increase in per capita income

metadata.original_paper_title: Association of County-Level Socioeconomic and Political Characteristics with Engagement in Social Distancing for COVID-19
